item.text: In this way, political ecology brings animals, plants, rivers, rocks and ecosystems into the order of social and political deliberation, assessing and sometimes insitutionalising the claims of the ‚Äòpropositions‚Äô that are vying for recognition. Such assessment is itself tentative, experimental and open to further probing.
Latour‚Äôs favourite metaphor here is one of diplomacy. The diplomat‚Äôs strength, he avers, lies in the approach that ‚Äòeverything is negotiable‚Äô ‚Äì even the meaning of ‚Äònegotiable‚Äô itself.

The diplomat is too canny to be fooled by the notion of using ‚Äòa common world‚Äô as a point of departure for a discussion of what ought to be done. The diplomat, in other words, is a kind of collective existentialist: she regards what is essential as what is manufactured through collective parley, not what is antecedently given by some mythical science of a mysteriously unified nature.
Here ares some notes from: [http://www.academia.edu/4492920/Review_of_Bruno_Latour_Politics_of_Nature Review of Bruno Latour Politics of Nature academia.edu]
Here ares some notes from: [http://www.academia.edu/4492920/Review_of_Bruno_Latour_Politics_of_Nature Review of Bruno Latour Politics of Nature academia.edu]

Political ecology is the study of the relationships between political, economic and social factors with environmental issues and changes. Political ecology differs from apolitical ecological studies by politicizing environmental issues and phenomena - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_ecology Wikipedia].
